text: And when he had said these things, he knelt down and prayed with them all.
speaker: Narrator

text: And there was much weeping on the part of all; they embraced Paul and kissed him,
speaker: Narrator

text: being sorrowful most of all because of the word he had spoken, that they would not see his face again. And they accompanied him to the ship.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when we had parted from them and set sail, we came by a straight course to Cos, and the next day to Rhodes, and from there to Patara.
speaker: Narrator

text: And having found a ship crossing to Phoenicia, we went aboard and set sail.
speaker: Narrator

text: When we had come in sight of Cyprus, leaving it on the left we sailed to Syria and landed at Tyre, for there the ship was to unload its cargo.
speaker: Narrator

text: And having sought out the disciples, we stayed there for seven days. And through the Spirit they were telling Paul not to go on to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: When our days there were ended, we departed and went on our journey, and they all, with wives and children, accompanied us until we were outside the city. And kneeling down on the beach, we prayed
speaker: Narrator

text: and said farewell to one another. Then we went on board the ship, and they returned home.
speaker: Narrator

text: When we had finished the voyage from Tyre, we arrived at Ptolemais, and we greeted the brothers and stayed with them for one day.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the next day we departed and came to Caesarea, and we entered the house of Philip the evangelist, who was one of the seven, and stayed with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had four unmarried daughters, who prophesied.
speaker: Narrator

text: While we were staying for many days, a prophet named Agabus came down from Judea.
speaker: Narrator

text: And coming to us, he took Paul's belt and bound his own feet and hands and said, “Thus says the Holy Spirit, ‘This is how the Jews at Jerusalem will bind the man who owns this belt and deliver him into the hands of the Gentiles.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: When we heard this, we and the people there urged him not to go up to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Paul answered, “What are you doing, weeping and breaking my heart? For I am ready not only to be imprisoned but even to die in Jerusalem for the name of the Lord Jesus.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And since he would not be persuaded, we ceased and said, “Let the will of the Lord be done.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After these days we got ready and went up to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: And some of the disciples from Caesarea went with us, bringing us to the house of Mnason of Cyprus, an early disciple, with whom we should lodge.
speaker: Narrator

text: When we had come to Jerusalem, the brothers received us gladly.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the following day Paul went in with us to James, and all the elders were present.
speaker: Narrator

text: After greeting them, he related one by one the things that God had done among the Gentiles through his ministry.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when they heard it, they glorified God. And they said to him, “You see, brother, how many thousands there are among the Jews of those who have believed. They are all zealous for the law,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they have been told about you that you teach all the Jews who are among the Gentiles to forsake Moses, telling them not to circumcise their children or walk according to our customs.
speaker: Narrator

text: What then is to be done? They will certainly hear that you have come.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do therefore what we tell you. We have four men who are under a vow;
speaker: Narrator

text: take these men and purify yourself along with them and pay their expenses, so that they may shave their heads. Thus all will know that there is nothing in what they have been told about you, but that you yourself also live in observance of the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: But as for the Gentiles who have believed, we have sent a letter with our judgement that they should abstain from what has been sacrificed to idols, and from blood, and from what has been strangled, and from sexual immorality.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Paul took the men, and the next day he purified himself along with them and went into the temple, giving notice when the days of purification would be fulfilled and the offering presented for each one of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the seven days were almost completed, the Jews from Asia, seeing him in the temple, stirred up the whole crowd and laid hands on him,
speaker: Narrator

text: crying out, “Men of Israel, help! This is the man who is teaching everyone everywhere against the people and the law and this place. Moreover, he even brought Greeks into the temple and has defiled this holy place.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For they had previously seen Trophimus the Ephesian with him in the city, and they supposed that Paul had brought him into the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the city was stirred up, and the people ran together. They seized Paul and dragged him out of the temple, and at once the gates were shut.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as they were seeking to kill him, word came to the tribune of the cohort that all Jerusalem was in confusion.
speaker: Narrator

text: He at once took soldiers and centurions and ran down to them. And when they saw the tribune and the soldiers, they stopped beating Paul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the tribune came up and arrested him and ordered him to be bound with two chains. He enquired who he was and what he had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some in the crowd were shouting one thing, some another. And as he could not learn the facts because of the uproar, he ordered him to be brought into the barracks.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when he came to the steps, he was actually carried by the soldiers because of the violence of the crowd,
speaker: Narrator

text: for the mob of the people followed, crying out, “Away with him!”
speaker: Narrator

text: As Paul was about to be brought into the barracks, he said to the tribune, “May I say something to you?” And he said, “Do you know Greek?
speaker: Narrator

text: Are you not the Egyptian, then, who recently stirred up a revolt and led the four thousand men of the Assassins out into the wilderness?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul replied, “I am a Jew, from Tarsus in Cilicia, a citizen of no obscure city. I beg you, permit me to speak to the people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And when he had given him permission, Paul, standing on the steps, motioned with his hand to the people. And when there was a great hush, he addressed them in the Hebrew language, saying:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Brothers and fathers, hear the defence that I now make before you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And when they heard that he was addressing them in the Hebrew language, they became even more quiet. And he said:
speaker: Narrator

text: “I am a Jew, born in Tarsus in Cilicia, but brought up in this city, educated at the feet of Gamaliel according to the strict manner of the law of our fathers, being zealous for God as all of you are this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: I persecuted this Way to the death, binding and delivering to prison both men and women,
speaker: Narrator

text: as the high priest and the whole council of elders can bear me witness. From them I received letters to the brothers, and I journeyed towards Damascus to take those also who were there and bring them in bonds to Jerusalem to be punished.
speaker: Narrator

text: “As I was on my way and drew near to Damascus, about noon a great light from heaven suddenly shone around me.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I fell to the ground and heard a voice saying to me, ‘Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me?’
speaker: Narrator

text: And I answered, ‘Who are you, Lord?’ And he said to me, ‘I am Jesus of Nazareth, whom you are persecuting.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now those who were with me saw the light but did not understand the voice of the one who was speaking to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I said, ‘What shall I do, Lord?’ And the Lord said to me, ‘Rise, and go into Damascus, and there you will be told all that is appointed for you to do.’
speaker: Narrator

text: And since I could not see because of the brightness of that light, I was led by the hand by those who were with me, and came into Damascus.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And one Ananias, a devout man according to the law, well spoken of by all the Jews who lived there,
speaker: Narrator

text: came to me, and standing by me said to me, ‘Brother Saul, receive your sight.’ And at that very hour I received my sight and saw him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said, ‘The God of our fathers appointed you to know his will, to see the Righteous One and to hear a voice from his mouth;
speaker: Narrator

text: for you will be a witness for him to everyone of what you have seen and heard.
speaker: Narrator

text: And now why do you wait? Rise and be baptized and wash away your sins, calling on his name.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “When I had returned to Jerusalem and was praying in the temple, I fell into a trance
speaker: Narrator

text: and saw him saying to me, ‘Make haste and get out of Jerusalem quickly, because they will not accept your testimony about me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: And I said, ‘Lord, they themselves know that in one synagogue after another I imprisoned and beat those who believed in you.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when the blood of Stephen your witness was being shed, I myself was standing by and approving and watching over the garments of those who killed him.’
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said to me, ‘Go, for I will send you far away to the Gentiles.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Up to this word they listened to him. Then they raised their voices and said, “Away with such a fellow from the earth! For he should not be allowed to live.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And as they were shouting and throwing off their cloaks and flinging dust into the air,
speaker: Narrator

text: the tribune ordered him to be brought into the barracks, saying that he should be examined by flogging, to find out why they were shouting against him like this.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when they had stretched him out for the whips, Paul said to the centurion who was standing by, “Is it lawful for you to flog a man who is a Roman citizen and uncondemned?”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the centurion heard this, he went to the tribune and said to him, “What are you about to do? For this man is a Roman citizen.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the tribune came and said to him, “Tell me, are you a Roman citizen?” And he said, “Yes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The tribune answered, “I bought this citizenship for a large sum.” Paul said, “But I am a citizen by birth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So those who were about to examine him withdrew from him immediately, and the tribune also was afraid, for he realized that Paul was a Roman citizen and that he had bound him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But on the next day, desiring to know the real reason why he was being accused by the Jews, he unbound him and commanded the chief priests and all the council to meet, and he brought Paul down and set him before them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And looking intently at the council, Paul said, “Brothers, I have lived my life before God in all good conscience up to this day.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the high priest Ananias commanded those who stood by him to strike him on the mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Paul said to him, “God is going to strike you, you whitewashed wall! Are you sitting to judge me according to the law, and yet contrary to the law you order me to be struck?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who stood by said, “Would you revile God's high priest?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Paul said, “I did not know, brothers, that he was the high priest, for it is written, ‘You shall not speak evil of a ruler of your people.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when Paul perceived that one part were Sadducees and the other Pharisees, he cried out in the council, “Brothers, I am a Pharisee, a son of Pharisees. It is with respect to the hope of the resurrection of the dead that I am on trial.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And when he had said this, a dissension arose between the Pharisees and the Sadducees, and the assembly was divided.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Sadducees say that there is no resurrection, nor angel, nor spirit, but the Pharisees acknowledge them all.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a great clamour arose, and some of the scribes of the Pharisees' party stood up and contended sharply, “We find nothing wrong in this man. What if a spirit or an angel spoke to him?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And when the dissension became violent, the tribune, afraid that Paul would be torn to pieces by them, commanded the soldiers to go down and take him away from among them by force and bring him into the barracks.
speaker: Narrator

text: The following night the Lord stood by him and said, “Take courage, for as you have testified to the facts about me in Jerusalem, so you must testify also in Rome.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When it was day, the Jews made a plot and bound themselves by an oath neither to eat nor drink till they had killed Paul.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were more than forty who made this conspiracy.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went to the chief priests and elders and said, “We have strictly bound ourselves by an oath to taste no food till we have killed Paul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now therefore you, along with the council, give notice to the tribune to bring him down to you, as though you were going to determine his case more exactly. And we are ready to kill him before he comes near.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the son of Paul's sister heard of their ambush, so he went and entered the barracks and told Paul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul called one of the centurions and said, “Take this young man to the tribune, for he has something to tell him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he took him and brought him to the tribune and said, “Paul the prisoner called me and asked me to bring this young man to you, as he has something to say to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The tribune took him by the hand, and going aside asked him privately, “What is it that you have to tell me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said, “The Jews have agreed to ask you to bring Paul down to the council tomorrow, as though they were going to enquire somewhat more closely about him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But do not be persuaded by them, for more than forty of their men are lying in ambush for him, who have bound themselves by an oath neither to eat nor drink till they have killed him. And now they are ready, waiting for your consent.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the tribune dismissed the young man, charging him, “Tell no one that you have informed me of these things.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he called two of the centurions and said, “Get ready two hundred soldiers, with seventy horsemen and two hundred spearmen to go as far as Caesarea at the third hour of the night.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also provide mounts for Paul to ride and bring him safely to Felix the governor.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he wrote a letter to this effect:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Claudius Lysias, to his Excellency the governor Felix, greetings.
speaker: Narrator

text: This man was seized by the Jews and was about to be killed by them when I came upon them with the soldiers and rescued him, having learned that he was a Roman citizen.
speaker: Narrator

text: And desiring to know the charge for which they were accusing him, I brought him down to their council.
speaker: Narrator

text: I found that he was being accused about questions of their law, but charged with nothing deserving death or imprisonment.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when it was disclosed to me that there would be a plot against the man, I sent him to you at once, ordering his accusers also to state before you what they have against him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the soldiers, according to their instructions, took Paul and brought him by night to Antipatris.
speaker: Narrator

text: And on the next day they returned to the barracks, letting the horsemen go on with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they had come to Caesarea and delivered the letter to the governor, they presented Paul also before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: On reading the letter, he asked what province he was from. And when he learned that he was from Cilicia,
speaker: Narrator

text: he said, “I will give you a hearing when your accusers arrive.” And he commanded him to be guarded in Herod's praetorium.
speaker: Narrator

text: And after five days the high priest Ananias came down with some elders and a spokesman, one Tertullus. They laid before the governor their case against Paul.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And when he had been summoned, Tertullus began to accuse him, saying:
“Since through you we enjoy much peace, and since by your foresight, most excellent Felix, reforms are being made for this nation,
speaker: Narrator

text: in every way and everywhere we accept this with all gratitude.
speaker: Narrator

text: But, to detain you no further, I beg you in your kindness to hear us briefly.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we have found this man a plague, one who stirs up riots among all the Jews throughout the world and is a ringleader of the sect of the Nazarenes.
speaker: Narrator

text: He even tried to profane the temple, but we seized him.
speaker: Narrator

text: By examining him yourself you will be able to find out from him about everything of which we accuse him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Jews also joined in the charge, affirming that all these things were so.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And when the governor had nodded to him to speak, Paul replied:
“Knowing that for many years you have been a judge over this nation, I cheerfully make my defence.
speaker: Narrator

text: You can verify that it is not more than twelve days since I went up to worship in Jerusalem,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they did not find me disputing with anyone or stirring up a crowd, either in the temple or in the synagogues or in the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Neither can they prove to you what they now bring up against me.
speaker: Narrator

text: But this I confess to you, that according to the Way, which they call a sect, I worship the God of our fathers, believing everything laid down by the Law and written in the Prophets,
speaker: Narrator

text: having a hope in God, which these men themselves accept, that there will be a resurrection of both the just and the unjust.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I always take pains to have a clear conscience towards both God and man.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now after several years I came to bring alms to my nation and to present offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: While I was doing this, they found me purified in the temple, without any crowd or tumult. But some Jews from Asia—
speaker: Narrator

text: they ought to be here before you and to make an accusation, should they have anything against me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or else let these men themselves say what wrongdoing they found when I stood before the council,
speaker: Narrator

text: other than this one thing that I cried out while standing among them: ‘It is with respect to the resurrection of the dead that I am on trial before you this day.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Felix, having a rather accurate knowledge of the Way, put them off, saying, “When Lysias the tribune comes down, I will decide your case.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he gave orders to the centurion that he should be kept in custody but have some liberty, and that none of his friends should be prevented from attending to his needs.
speaker: Narrator

text: After some days Felix came with his wife Drusilla, who was Jewish, and he sent for Paul and heard him speak about faith in Christ Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as he reasoned about righteousness and self-control and the coming judgement, Felix was alarmed and said, “Go away for the present. When I get an opportunity I will summon you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: At the same time he hoped that money would be given him by Paul. So he sent for him often and conversed with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When two years had elapsed, Felix was succeeded by Porcius Festus. And desiring to do the Jews a favour, Felix left Paul in prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now three days after Festus had arrived in the province, he went up to Jerusalem from Caesarea.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the chief priests and the principal men of the Jews laid out their case against Paul, and they urged him,
speaker: Narrator

text: asking as a favour against Paul that he summon him to Jerusalem—because they were planning an ambush to kill him on the way.
speaker: Narrator

text: Festus replied that Paul was being kept at Caesarea and that he himself intended to go there shortly.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So,” said he, “let the men of authority among you go down with me, and if there is anything wrong about the man, let them bring charges against him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After he stayed among them not more than eight or ten days, he went down to Caesarea. And the next day he took his seat on the tribunal and ordered Paul to be brought.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he had arrived, the Jews who had come down from Jerusalem stood around him, bringing many and serious charges against him that they could not prove.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul argued in his defence, “Neither against the law of the Jews, nor against the temple, nor against Caesar have I committed any offence.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Festus, wishing to do the Jews a favour, said to Paul, “Do you wish to go up to Jerusalem and there be tried on these charges before me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Paul said, “I am standing before Caesar's tribunal, where I ought to be tried. To the Jews I have done no wrong, as you yourself know very well.
speaker: Narrator

text: If then I am a wrongdoer and have committed anything for which I deserve to die, I do not seek to escape death. But if there is nothing to their charges against me, no one can give me up to them. I appeal to Caesar.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Festus, when he had conferred with his council, answered, “To Caesar you have appealed; to Caesar you shall go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when some days had passed, Agrippa the king and Bernice arrived at Caesarea and greeted Festus.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as they stayed there many days, Festus laid Paul's case before the king, saying, “There is a man left prisoner by Felix,
speaker: Narrator

text: and when I was at Jerusalem, the chief priests and the elders of the Jews laid out their case against him, asking for a sentence of condemnation against him.
speaker: Narrator

text: I answered them that it was not the custom of the Romans to give up anyone before the accused met the accusers face to face and had opportunity to make his defence concerning the charge laid against him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So when they came together here, I made no delay, but on the next day took my seat on the tribunal and ordered the man to be brought.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the accusers stood up, they brought no charge in his case of such evils as I supposed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rather they had certain points of dispute with him about their own religion and about a certain Jesus, who was dead, but whom Paul asserted to be alive.
speaker: Narrator

text: Being at a loss how to investigate these questions, I asked whether he wanted to go to Jerusalem and be tried there regarding them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when Paul had appealed to be kept in custody for the decision of the emperor, I ordered him to be held until I could send him to Caesar.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Agrippa said to Festus, “I would like to hear the man myself.” “Tomorrow”, said he, “you will hear him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So on the next day Agrippa and Bernice came with great pomp, and they entered the audience hall with the military tribunes and the prominent men of the city. Then, at the command of Festus, Paul was brought in.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Festus said, “King Agrippa and all who are present with us, you see this man about whom the whole Jewish people petitioned me, both in Jerusalem and here, shouting that he ought not to live any longer.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I found that he had done nothing deserving death. And as he himself appealed to the emperor, I decided to go ahead and send him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I have nothing definite to write to my lord about him. Therefore I have brought him before you all, and especially before you, King Agrippa, so that, after we have examined him, I may have something to write.
speaker: Narrator

text: For it seems to me unreasonable, in sending a prisoner, not to indicate the charges against him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Agrippa said to Paul, “You have permission to speak for yourself.” Then Paul stretched out his hand and made his defence:
speaker: Narrator

text: “I consider myself fortunate that it is before you, King Agrippa, I am going to make my defence today against all the accusations of the Jews,
speaker: Narrator

text: especially because you are familiar with all the customs and controversies of the Jews. Therefore I beg you to listen to me patiently.
speaker: Narrator

text: “My manner of life from my youth, spent from the beginning among my own nation and in Jerusalem, is known by all the Jews.
speaker: Narrator

text: They have known for a long time, if they are willing to testify, that according to the strictest party of our religion I have lived as a Pharisee.
speaker: Narrator

text: And now I stand here on trial because of my hope in the promise made by God to our fathers,
speaker: Narrator

text: to which our twelve tribes hope to attain, as they earnestly worship night and day. And for this hope I am accused by Jews, O king!
speaker: Narrator

text: Why is it thought incredible by any of you that God raises the dead?
speaker: Narrator

text: “I myself was convinced that I ought to do many things in opposing the name of Jesus of Nazareth.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I did so in Jerusalem. I not only locked up many of the saints in prison after receiving authority from the chief priests, but when they were put to death I cast my vote against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I punished them often in all the synagogues and tried to make them blaspheme, and in raging fury against them I persecuted them even to foreign cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: “In this connection I journeyed to Damascus with the authority and commission of the chief priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: At midday, O king, I saw on the way a light from heaven, brighter than the sun, that shone around me and those who journeyed with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when we had all fallen to the ground, I heard a voice saying to me in the Hebrew language, ‘Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me? It is hard for you to kick against the goads.’
speaker: Narrator

text: And I said, ‘Who are you, Lord?’ And the Lord said, ‘I am Jesus whom you are persecuting.
speaker: Narrator

text: But rise and stand upon your feet, for I have appeared to you for this purpose, to appoint you as a servant and witness to the things in which you have seen me and to those in which I will appear to you,
speaker: Narrator

text: delivering you from your people and from the Gentiles—to whom I am sending you
speaker: Narrator

text: to open their eyes, so that they may turn from darkness to light and from the power of Satan to God, that they may receive forgiveness of sins and a place among those who are sanctified by faith in me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Therefore, O King Agrippa, I was not disobedient to the heavenly vision,
speaker: Narrator

text: but declared first to those in Damascus, then in Jerusalem and throughout all the region of Judea, and also to the Gentiles, that they should repent and turn to God, performing deeds in keeping with their repentance.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this reason the Jews seized me in the temple and tried to kill me.
speaker: Narrator

text: To this day I have had the help that comes from God, and so I stand here testifying both to small and great, saying nothing but what the prophets and Moses said would come to pass:
speaker: Narrator

text: that the Christ must suffer and that, by being the first to rise from the dead, he would proclaim light both to our people and to the Gentiles.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And as he was saying these things in his defence, Festus said with a loud voice, “Paul, you are out of your mind; your great learning is driving you out of your mind.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Paul said, “I am not out of my mind, most excellent Festus, but I am speaking true and rational words.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the king knows about these things, and to him I speak boldly. For I am persuaded that none of these things has escaped his notice, for this has not been done in a corner.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Agrippa, do you believe the prophets? I know that you believe.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Agrippa said to Paul, “In a short time would you persuade me to be a Christian?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Paul said, “Whether short or long, I would to God that not only you but also all who hear me this day might become such as I am—except for these chains.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king rose, and the governor and Bernice and those who were sitting with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when they had withdrawn, they said to one another, “This man is doing nothing to deserve death or imprisonment.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Agrippa said to Festus, “This man could have been set free if he had not appealed to Caesar.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And when it was decided that we should sail for Italy, they delivered Paul and some other prisoners to a centurion of the Augustan Cohort named Julius.
speaker: Narrator

text: And embarking in a ship of Adramyttium, which was about to sail to the ports along the coast of Asia, we put to sea, accompanied by Aristarchus, a Macedonian from Thessalonica.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day we put in at Sidon. And Julius treated Paul kindly and gave him leave to go to his friends and be cared for.
speaker: Narrator

text: And putting out to sea from there we sailed under the lee of Cyprus, because the winds were against us.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when we had sailed across the open sea along the coast of Cilicia and Pamphylia, we came to Myra in Lycia.
speaker: Narrator

text: There the centurion found a ship of Alexandria sailing for Italy and put us on board.
speaker: Narrator

text: We sailed slowly for a number of days and arrived with difficulty off Cnidus, and as the wind did not allow us to go farther, we sailed under the lee of Crete off Salmone.
speaker: Narrator

text: Coasting along it with difficulty, we came to a place called Fair Havens, near which was the city of Lasea.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since much time had passed, and the voyage was now dangerous because even the Fast was already over, Paul advised them,
speaker: Narrator

text: saying, “Sirs, I perceive that the voyage will be with injury and much loss, not only of the cargo and the ship, but also of our lives.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the centurion paid more attention to the pilot and to the owner of the ship than to what Paul said.
speaker: Narrator

text: And because the harbour was not suitable to spend the winter in, the majority decided to put out to sea from there, on the chance that somehow they could reach Phoenix, a harbour of Crete, facing both southwest and northwest, and spend the winter there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when the south wind blew gently, supposing that they had obtained their purpose, they weighed anchor and sailed along Crete, close to the shore.
speaker: Narrator

text: But soon a tempestuous wind, called the northeaster, struck down from the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when the ship was caught and could not face the wind, we gave way to it and were driven along.
speaker: Narrator

text: Running under the lee of a small island called Cauda, we managed with difficulty to secure the ship's boat.
speaker: Narrator

text: After hoisting it up, they used supports to undergird the ship. Then, fearing that they would run aground on the Syrtis, they lowered the gear, and thus they were driven along.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since we were violently storm-tossed, they began the next day to jettison the cargo.
speaker: Narrator

text: And on the third day they threw the ship's tackle overboard with their own hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: When neither sun nor stars appeared for many days, and no small tempest lay on us, all hope of our being saved was at last abandoned.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since they had been without food for a long time, Paul stood up among them and said, “Men, you should have listened to me and not have set sail from Crete and incurred this injury and loss.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet now I urge you to take heart, for there will be no loss of life among you, but only of the ship.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this very night there stood before me an angel of the God to whom I belong and whom I worship,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he said, ‘Do not be afraid, Paul; you must stand before Caesar. And behold, God has granted you all those who sail with you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So take heart, men, for I have faith in God that it will be exactly as I have been told.
speaker: Narrator

text: But we must run aground on some island.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the fourteenth night had come, as we were being driven across the Adriatic Sea, about midnight the sailors suspected that they were nearing land.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they took a sounding and found twenty fathoms. A little farther on they took a sounding again and found fifteen fathoms.
speaker: Narrator

text: And fearing that we might run on the rocks, they let down four anchors from the stern and prayed for day to come.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as the sailors were seeking to escape from the ship, and had lowered the ship's boat into the sea under pretence of laying out anchors from the bow,
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul said to the centurion and the soldiers, “Unless these men stay in the ship, you cannot be saved.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the soldiers cut away the ropes of the ship's boat and let it go.
speaker: Narrator

text: As day was about to dawn, Paul urged them all to take some food, saying, “Today is the fourteenth day that you have continued in suspense and without food, having taken nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore I urge you to take some food. For it will give you strength, for not a hair is to perish from the head of any of you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And when he had said these things, he took bread, and giving thanks to God in the presence of all he broke it and began to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they all were encouraged and ate some food themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: (We were in all 276 persons in the ship.)
speaker: Narrator

text: And when they had eaten enough, they lightened the ship, throwing out the wheat into the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when it was day, they did not recognize the land, but they noticed a bay with a beach, on which they planned if possible to run the ship ashore.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they cast off the anchors and left them in the sea, at the same time loosening the ropes that tied the rudders. Then hoisting the foresail to the wind they made for the beach.
speaker: Narrator

text: But striking a reef, they ran the vessel aground. The bow stuck and remained immovable, and the stern was being broken up by the surf.
speaker: Narrator

text: The soldiers' plan was to kill the prisoners, lest any should swim away and escape.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the centurion, wishing to save Paul, kept them from carrying out their plan. He ordered those who could swim to jump overboard first and make for the land,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the rest on planks or on pieces of the ship. And so it was that all were brought safely to land.
speaker: Narrator

text: After we were brought safely through, we then learned that the island was called Malta.
speaker: Narrator

text: The native people showed us unusual kindness, for they kindled a fire and welcomed us all, because it had begun to rain and was cold.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Paul had gathered a bundle of sticks and put them on the fire, a viper came out because of the heat and fastened on his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the native people saw the creature hanging from his hand, they said to one another, “No doubt this man is a murderer. Though he has escaped from the sea, Justice has not allowed him to live.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He, however, shook off the creature into the fire and suffered no harm.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were waiting for him to swell up or suddenly fall down dead. But when they had waited a long time and saw no misfortune come to him, they changed their minds and said that he was a god.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now in the neighbourhood of that place were lands belonging to the chief man of the island, named Publius, who received us and entertained us hospitably for three days.
speaker: Narrator

text: It happened that the father of Publius lay sick with fever and dysentery. And Paul visited him and prayed, and putting his hands on him healed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when this had taken place, the rest of the people on the island who had diseases also came and were cured.
speaker: Narrator

text: They also honoured us greatly, and when we were about to sail, they put on board whatever we needed.
speaker: Narrator

text: After three months we set sail in a ship that had wintered in the island, a ship of Alexandria, with the twin gods as a figurehead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Putting in at Syracuse, we stayed there for three days.
speaker: Narrator

text: And from there we made a circuit and arrived at Rhegium. And after one day a south wind sprang up, and on the second day we came to Puteoli.
speaker: Narrator

text: There we found brothers and were invited to stay with them for seven days. And so we came to Rome.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the brothers there, when they heard about us, came as far as the Forum of Appius and Three Taverns to meet us. On seeing them, Paul thanked God and took courage.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when we came into Rome, Paul was allowed to stay by himself, with the soldier that guarded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: After three days he called together the local leaders of the Jews, and when they had gathered, he said to them, “Brothers, though I had done nothing against our people or the customs of our fathers, yet I was delivered as a prisoner from Jerusalem into the hands of the Romans.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they had examined me, they wished to set me at liberty, because there was no reason for the death penalty in my case.
speaker: Narrator

text: But because the Jews objected, I was compelled to appeal to Caesar—though I had no charge to bring against my nation.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this reason, therefore, I have asked to see you and speak with you, since it is because of the hope of Israel that I am wearing this chain.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And they said to him, “We have received no letters from Judea about you, and none of the brothers coming here has reported or spoken any evil about you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But we desire to hear from you what your views are, for with regard to this sect we know that everywhere it is spoken against.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When they had appointed a day for him, they came to him at his lodging in greater numbers. From morning till evening he expounded to them, testifying to the kingdom of God and trying to convince them about Jesus both from the Law of Moses and from the Prophets.
speaker: Narrator

text: And some were convinced by what he said, but others disbelieved.
speaker: Narrator

text: And disagreeing among themselves, they departed after Paul had made one statement: “The Holy Spirit was right in saying to your fathers through Isaiah the prophet:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“‘Go to this people, and say,
You will indeed hear but never understand,
    and you will indeed see but never perceive.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For this people's heart has grown dull,
    and with their ears they can barely hear,
    and their eyes they have closed;
lest they should see with their eyes
    and hear with their ears
and understand with their heart
    and turn, and I would heal them.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore let it be known to you that this salvation of God has been sent to the Gentiles; they will listen.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He lived there two whole years at his own expense, and welcomed all who came to him,
speaker: Narrator

text: proclaiming the kingdom of God and teaching about the Lord Jesus Christ with all boldness and without hindrance.
speaker: Narrator
